items.title: Celebrating a full house of Ofsted ‘Outstanding’ Reports
items.snippet: Following Ofsted inspections across the Midlands and South, North East and North West and with Yorkshire already holding an ‘Ofsted Outstanding’ accreditation, every one of our offices have once again been awarded the highest possible rating of ‘Outstanding’ across all areas of our service. The post Celebrating a full house of Ofsted ‘Outstanding’ Reports appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
2025 has been a truly exceptional year for Swiis Foster Care. Following Ofsted inspections across the Midlands and South, North East and North West and with Yorkshire already holding an ‘Ofsted Outstanding’ accreditation, every one of our offices have once again been awarded the highest possible rating of ‘Outstanding’ across all areas of our service.

Consistently achieving Ofsted’s highest rating is an exceptional accomplishment within the fostering sector, attained by only a small number of agencies nationwide. Through sustained excellence and unwavering commitment to children and young people, Swiis stands among a select and respected small group of UK fostering providers currently holding multiple ‘Outstanding’ ratings simultaneously.

Ofsted’s inspection report celebrates not only the quality of provision but the life-changing impact of Swiis’s work, noting:

“(Swiis), the independent fostering agency provides highly effective services that consistently exceed the standards of good. The actions of the independent fostering agency contribute to significantly improved outcomes and positive experiences for children and young people.”

What Does Being an Ofsted ‘Outstanding’ Fostering Agency Mean?

Being rated ‘Outstanding’ by Ofsted is more than an impressive achievement. It is a clear indication that children and young people experience the highest quality care and support possible, enabling them to achieve their goals and ambitions that they may not have been able to. It reflects consistently excellent practice, robust safeguarding, and exceptional leadership across every part of our agency.

For the Children and Young People in Our Care

For children, this means they feel safe, valued, and genuinely heard by our foster carers and staff. They are supported to grow in confidence, achieve their goals, and experience the stability and encouragement they need to thrive. It shows that their voices matter and that their wellbeing is at the heart of everything we do.

For Our Foster Carers

For foster carers, this recognition reflects the high-quality training, guidance and round-the-clock support they receive, as well as the positive, lasting difference they make to the lives of the children in their care. Swiis foster carers are among the best in the sector, consistently providing nurturing, stable homes where children and young people feel safe, valued and able to thrive.

Swiis foster carers know they are never alone. They are part of a supportive community, backed by a dedicated team who are always there, listening, guiding and standing alongside them, fully committed to their success and to the wellbeing and future of every child and young person in their care.

As a Fostering Agency

Ofsted only awards ‘Outstanding’ when a fostering agency consistently goes above and beyond for their foster carers and the children within their care. Having consistently ‘Outstanding’ ratings in all areas across our Midlands and South, North East, Yorkshire and North West offices is an exceptionally proud achievement for all Swiis staff.

This accomplishment reflects the dedication, compassion and professionalism of every member of the Swiis team. It is a testament to the hard work our staff put in every day and to our unwavering commitment to achieving the best possible outcomes for children and young people.

Highlights From Our Ofsted Reports

Across the Midlands and South, North East, Yorkshire and North West, children receive nurturing, individualised care that helps them make exceptional progress. Many enjoy long-term, stable home arrangements, building trusting and meaningful relationships with their foster carers.

Below, we have shared just a small selection of the wonderful feedback highlighted by Ofsted. If you would like to explore our reports in full, you can find them on the Government website here:

North East Ofsted Report North West Ofsted Report Midlands & South Ofsted Report Yorkshire Ofsted Report

Support for Children and Young People’s Educational Needs

Education is a key strength, with children attending school regularly, consistently achieving above expectations, and benefiting from specialist support tailored to their individual learning needs. Swiis places strong emphasis on children’s engagement with education, ensuring their commitment and participation are actively supported. Every achievement, big or small, is recognised and celebrated by our teams, helping children build confidence and feel empowered to aspire to and reach their goals.

“Specialist and bespoke support is provided by a dedicated team that works alongside children to break down any barriers to their learning.” – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

“Children’s education and learning progress are at the forefront of the agency’s practice.” – North East Ofsted Report

Swiis Education Advisors work closely with children and foster carers to understand each child’s unique learning needs and provide tailored guidance to overcome challenges. By prioritising education, Swiis ensures that every child and young person has the best possible opportunity to succeed, develop confidence, and achieve their full potential, while foster carers feel fully supported in helping children reach their goals.

Our Dedicated Stability and Support Team

Swiis’s Stability & Support Team provides foster carers with an additional layer of personalised guidance and one-to-one support, helping them respond confidently to any concerns or behaviours a child or young person may present. From the very beginning of their fostering journey, carers can access practical advice and proven strategies to support them through any challenging moments.  The Stability and Support Team can be accessed directly by the foster carer if preferred and is in addition to the exceptional daily support of the social work teams.  This wrap around support ensures foster carers are well equipped to create safe, nurturing environments where children can thrive, grow and overcome barriers they may face.

“Foster carers feel exceptionally well supported and valued by agency staff, which impacts positively on the outcomes of children who are thriving in their foster families.” – North West Ofsted Report

Exceptional Safeguarding

Safeguarding is at the heart of everything we do at Swiis. Children and young people feel safe, supported and valued in our foster homes, cared for by experienced foster carers and supported by highly skilled and committed social work teams. We operate robust and comprehensive safeguarding processes to ensure the highest standards of safety and wellbeing for every child in our care.

Safeguarding is also central to our recruitment, assessment and approval processes. All foster carers and Swiis staff go through rigorous checks and preparation, ensuring they are well trained, confident and fully supported in their role. This strong safeguarding framework promotes stability and enables foster carers to provide safe, nurturing homes where children can thrive.

“Safeguarding children is at the centre of the agency.” – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

At Swiis, every decision and action prioritises the safety and well-being of children. This gives foster carers confidence that they are fully supported when protecting children, knowing they are not alone in ensuring the highest standards of care. Children, in turn, feel secure, protected, and able to build trust with the foster carers caring for them.

Comprehensive and Relevant Training

Swiis provides foster carers with comprehensive and practical training, giving them the knowledge and confidence they need to meet children’s diverse needs. Well-trained foster carers can respond effectively to both every day and complex situations, helping children feel secure, supported, and understood at all times.

“Highly effective post-approval training ensures that foster carers have the relevant skills and knowledge to undertake the fostering role.” – North West Ofsted Report

Child-Focused Leadership and Staff

Swiis is led by experienced leaders who provide strong oversight and inspire continuous improvement. Staff morale is high, workloads are manageable, and teams work closely together to deliver consistent, high-quality care. All regions have strong partnerships with other professionals to ensure children remain at the centre of all practice.

“Foster carers have provided overwhelmingly positive feedback about the support they receive from the agency.” – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

Foster carers consistently report feeling valued, supported, and heard. This strengthens fostering home-finding arrangements, enabling children to thrive in stable, nurturing homes where their emotional and developmental needs are met.

“Staff morale is high, and staff say that they love their job.” – North East Ofsted Report

Motivated and passionate staff ensure children receive consistent, high-quality care. When staff feel proud and inspired by their work, it directly benefits foster carers and children, creating a supportive environment where everyone can flourish.

“Social workers have manageable caseloads and are in weekly contact with their foster carers.” – North West Ofsted Report

Regular, meaningful contact allows social workers to provide timely guidance, reassurance, and practical support. This ensures foster carers are equipped to meet children’s needs effectively, helping children feel safe, cared for, and supported at every stage of their fostering journey.

A Huge Thank You!

We would like to extend our heartfelt thanks to our foster carers, the children, and young people in our care, and every member of the Swiis team. Your dedication, commitment, and collaboration are at the heart of these ‘Outstanding’ achievements. These Ofsted results celebrate the care, passion, and teamwork that make Swiis a truly exceptional fostering service.

items.title: Swiis Foster Care: Highlights of an Extraordinary 2025
items.snippet: 2025 has been a year where children have thrived, foster carers have felt truly supported, and our teams have gone above and beyond to deliver life-changing care. The post Swiis Foster Care: Highlights of an Extraordinary 2025 appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
2025 has been a truly remarkable year for Swiis Foster Care, a year defined by commitment, compassion, and collective excellence. Above all else, it has been a year where children have thrived, foster carers have felt truly supported, and our teams have gone above and beyond to deliver life-changing care.

A Landmark Year: Ofsted Outstanding – Three Times Over

The pinnacle of 2025 came in the latter part of the year, when Swiis Foster Care achieved an exceptional milestone: three Ofsted inspections, each awarded Outstanding across all areas. This achievement means that all Swiis regions, including Yorkshire, the North East, the North West, the Midlands and South, are officially rated Outstanding, the highest possible recognition across all areas of our service.

These inspections were embraced by every team member as an opportunity to showcase the exceptional work we do together. An Ofsted Outstanding rating is more than an accolade, it is recognition that children are not only safe but flourishing, supported by stable arrangements, highly skilled foster carers, and leadership that is relentless in its pursuit of excellence.

An outstanding award also reflects the fact that our foster carers are exceptionally well trained and supported, with robust safeguarding, strong professional relationships, and a culture of continuous improvement that truly puts children first.

“The independent fostering agency provides highly effective services that consistently exceed the standards of good. The actions of the independent fostering agency contribute to significantly improved outcomes and positive experiences for children and young people.” – Ofsted, 2025

North East Ofsted Report North West Ofsted Report Midlands & South Ofsted Report Yorkshire Ofsted Report

Children Thriving Through Stability and Belonging

At the heart of everything we do are our children, and this year, their achievements have been nothing short of inspiring. Across Swiis Foster Care, children have experienced increased stability, improved emotional well-being, and the confidence that comes from feeling safe, valued, and listened to.

Many of our children have made significant personal progress, overcoming early trauma with the help of consistent, nurturing foster arrangements. These achievements, whether it’s improved school attendance, renewed self-belief, learning new skills or simply learning to trust again, are powerful reminders of the impact that exceptional foster care can have on a child’s life.

Foster Carers: The Beating Heart of Swiis Foster Care

In 2025, Swiis Foster Care truly demonstrated that we are the agency of choice. We recruited the highest number of foster carers in our history, far exceeding the average for fostering agencies nationally. This extraordinary achievement reflects the trust carers place in Swiis and the reputation we have built for outstanding support, training, and care.

Our foster carers continue to show unwavering dedication, opening their hearts and homes to children who need them most. Their resilience, compassion, and commitment underpin every success we celebrate.

Support That Never Sleeps: 24/7, Every Day

At Swiis Foster Care, support doesn’t stop at office hours. Our foster carers have access to guidance and reassurance 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, ensuring that no concern, challenge, or unexpected situation is faced alone. This constant availability provides confidence, reassurance, and peace of mind, a cornerstone of our outstanding practice.

Rachel’s Fostering Story

“From the very beginning, Swiis has been an incredible support system. They have listened to me when discussing my choices and have always supported my decisions. I truly believe we work as a team, and I always feel listened to, and I plan to continue fostering with Swiis until I retire.”

Read Rachel’s Fostering Story

Bianca’s Fostering Story

“Swiis Foster Care have supported us every step of the way. The assessment process and initial training were both realistic and supportive, and we have made positive relationships with all the Swiis staff. What makes Swiis different is that the teams are genuinely interested in carers and the children, and that makes a big difference.”

Read Bianca’s Fostering Story

Going Beyond: The Stability and Support Team

A few years ago, Swiis Foster Care took an innovative step to further enhance support by developing a specialist Stability and Support Team. Their role is to work directly with foster carers, offering tailored advice, practical strategies, and specialist guidance around behaviours and complex needs.

In 2025, this team had its busiest year yet. Demand grew as carers increasingly accessed this invaluable support, a clear testament to how impactful and trusted the service has become. In response, we expanded the team to ensure every foster carer receives timely, expert help when they need it most.

The team also introduced specialist forum groups and topical webinar training, with subjects chosen by our foster carers themselves. This collaborative approach has empowered carers, strengthened peer connections, and further enhanced the quality of care provided to children.

View The Stability & Support Team

Looking Ahead to 2026

As we reflect on 2025, we do so with immense pride. This was a year of outstanding achievement, heartfelt dedication, and genuine transformation for children, foster carers, and staff alike.

Together, we have shown what is possible when care, expertise, and passion come together. And as we look to the future, one thing remains certain: Swiis Foster Care will continue to go above and beyond, because every child deserves nothing less.

As we move into 2026, our commitment remains unwavering. At Swiis Foster Care, we will continue to evolve and strengthen the support we provide to both our foster carers and the children and young people in their care. Everything we do is guided by one clear purpose: ensuring that every child can feel safe, nurtured, and supported to achieve their full potential.

For those choosing to begin their fostering journey with Swiis, we are committed to making that experience as supportive, flexible, and stress-free as possible. From the very first conversation, through assessment, approval, and beyond, our focus is on supporting our carers every step of the way.

During the next few months, we will be sharing more about the wonderful achievements of our children, celebrating their progress, resilience, and successes. We will also be highlighting the vital role of our social work teams and our foster carers, alongside the specialist provision offered by our Stability and Support Team, giving greater insight into how this enhanced support continues to make a meaningful difference for carers and children alike.

In addition, we will be sharing more details about the feedback from our Ofsted Outstanding inspection outcomes, helping to demonstrate what outstanding practice looks like and how it directly benefits the children we support.

items.content:
Thinking about becoming a foster parent, but not sure where to start?  

We have just launched our ‘Let’s Talk About Fostering‘ podcast, where you can learn everything there is to know about being a foster parent, from how to get started to what it’s really like day-to-day.  

In the latest episode, host Faye chats with our incredible foster parent Alison, who has been fostering with FCA since 2017. Alison is a single foster mum who cares for teenagers, something she describes as ‘brilliant fun if you can get on their level.’ 

She talks honestly about leaving her job after 32 years, going through the assessment and panel process, the training and support she receives from us here at FCA, and what it felt like to welcome a young person into her home for the very first time. 

What’s covered in this episode? 

Faye and Alison delve into everything you need to know about starting your fostering journey, offering a glimpse into the life of a foster parent with FCA.  

In this episode, they chat about: 

  • Things to think about at the start of your fostering journey.  
  • Why your age, being single, and not having children can be benefits, not barriers.  
  • What it’s like to foster teenagers. 
  • The reality of the fostering assessment and panel process. 
  • What training with FCA looks like – and why you don’t need experience to join us. 
  • How it feels to welcome your first foster child home.  
  • FCA’s ongoing support and community of foster parents. 
  • How fostering changes your life.  
  • The myths surrounding children in care. 
  • Alison’s advice for anyone thinking about fostering.  
  • Alison’s favourite fostering moment.  

“Fostering has brought me so much joy, and I would hope it’s brought the children so much too.” 

 

Start your fostering journey today 

To learn more about becoming a foster parent, call us on 0800 023 4561 or submit an enquiry. Our friendly and knowledgeable team are ready to answer your questions and help you get started on your fostering journey.

items.title: Debbie’s 15 Years of Fostering
items.snippet: Debbie has been fostering with FCA North West for 15 years. Over that time, she’s cared for many different children - from young babies and parent and child placements right through to older teenagers. The post Debbie’s 15 Years of Fostering appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
How it all began

Fostering had always been at the back of Debbie’s mind. She liked the idea of helping children who needed a safe, stable home but she just wasn’t sure when the right moment would be.

“I’d always thought about fostering and thought it would be a nice thing to do,” she says. “A friend of mine started fostering and said, ‘Would you like me to give you my social worker’s number?’ And it all started from there.”

Moments that make it all worthwhile

Over the years, Debbie has welcomed many children with different backgrounds and needs. One young person stands out.

“We had a child come to live with us who was quite challenging at the time,” she explains. “He was from another country, and his culture was very different to ours. It was challenging for him and for us.”

Debbie never expected him to stay in touch — but he did.

“When he left, I didn’t think he would keep in touch, but he did and he still does to this day. Any problems he has, or difficulties, or even achievements, he’ll always come back and tell us, which is lovely.”

Another moment that means a lot to Debbie involves a young person she cares for now.

“When she came to live with us, she found it quite difficult — especially around men, including my husband,” Debbie says. “As time went on, she got more relaxed. The moment she just went up and gave him a hug… that was really, really nice. That was one of my favourite moments.”

The qualities that matter

Debbie believes empathy is the most important part of fostering.

“You need to have that empathy for children because they come from all different backgrounds,” she says. “For somebody to just turn up at your home and have to live with another family – it’s really, really hard. I’d find it difficult, let alone a little child.”

Support that’s always there

For Debbie, FCA’s support has made a big difference to her fostering journey.

“We receive lots of support from FCA, and it can be in different ways,” she explains. “If there’s something we’re finding difficult or challenging, we can always go and ask. If there’s something we’re not sure of, there’s always somebody on the end of the phone. Even if our social worker’s off, there’s always someone we can contact.”

Her advice?

After 15 years, Debbie still loves fostering – and she encourages others to explore it too.

“If you’re thinking about fostering, it’s worth finding out more. You don’t have to know everything, you just need to care. The rest comes with support.”

items.snippet: We’re excited to launch our brand-new podcast, “Let’s Talk About Fostering”. items.content:
We’re excited to share our brand-new podcast, Let’s Talk About Fostering. Hosted by Faye, the podcast brings together real voices from across the Polaris Community, including care-experienced people, foster parents, those who grew up in fostering households, and fostering professionals. Together, they talk openly and honestly about what fostering is really like – the ups, the challenges, and everything in between.

In the first three episodes, you’ll hear from Jo August, our CEO, who grew up in a fostering family and brings over 35 years’ experience in the sector; Alison and Theresa, foster parents, sharing their personal journeys; and Jim McGarrigle, Responsible Individual across a number of our fostering services.

All offering insight from years of professional experience. Together, they explore fostering from every angle, grounded in real life, not theory.

The podcast is full of honest stories from foster parents, myth-busting conversations about fostering, practical tips, and insights from the journey. You’ll also hear from care-experienced staff, people who grew up in fostering, and long-time foster carers. It’s perfect for anyone who is curious about fostering, unsure if it’s right for them, or looking for reassurance from people who’ve been there.

It’s a space to listen, learn, and reflect, hearing real experiences that can help you decide what fostering might look like for you.

items.title: From Empty Nest to a Full Home – Tracy’s Fostering Story
items.snippet: Tracy shares how fostering with FCA helped her turn an empty nest into a loving home, keeping siblings together and helping children thrive. The post From Empty Nest to a Full Home – Tracy’s Fostering Story appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
Tracy, from Southport in Merseyside, started fostering with her husband in 2022

When her birth children grew older and became more independent, she felt a shift at home, that familiar “empty nest” feeling and knew she was ready for a new challenge.

“When my birth children left home, it was like a bit of an empty nest,” she says. “They went to high school, became more independent, and I wanted a new career in childcare. So, I looked into fostering, got some information, found out about it… had lots of appointments, found out loads of details, and then decided to give it a go.”

Tracy’s introduction to fostering

Tracy’s first three years as a foster parent were with her local authority in Shropshire. But after relocating to the North West, she felt ready for a fresh start.

“On our relocation, I got in touch with a foster carer who recommended FCA,” she explains. “So I got in touch with the agency. Somebody came round, we had a chat, and we went through the process again and joined FCA North West.”

Keeping siblings together

Their first foster child was part of a sibling group, but only one child could be placed with them at the time. It made a lasting impact.

“We saw the grief of a child who’d been separated from her siblings,” Tracy says. “So when she left our care, we decided we wanted a bigger family home so we could foster sibling groups. We wanted to keep them together.”

That decision shaped everything that came next. Now Tracy and her husband care for three sisters, aged seven, eight and nine. “I’ve had them for the last three years,” she says proudly. “They’re long-term matched with me.”

Watching children thrive

For Tracy, the real highlights of fostering are the moments of growth.

“The highlights of fostering, I’d say, are seeing the child thrive, grow and smile in your care,” she says. “To know that they can be happy and get on with their lives and still have contact with their birth family.”

One teenager stands out in her mind.

“She came into care having lots of difficulties at school. Through care, nurture and help, we got her back into a mainstream school. We got her the help she needed — the diagnoses she needed. She was actually dyslexic, but she’d been classed as a naughty child, a distracted child. With support, she sat her exams. That was a massive change.”

“The support with FCA is absolutely amazing.”

When Tracy talks about FCA, she doesn’t hesitate. “The support with FCA is absolutely amazing — one of the main reasons we made the decision to go with this agency,” she says.

And the support comes in all shapes and sizes.

“It’s foster carer get-togethers, activities they put on for the children — including birth families. We have monthly support groups in the North West. We meet at the Chorley office. There’s always something going on.”

Her advice to others?

“If you’re thinking about fostering, I’d say give FCA a call. They’ll answer any questions you have on the phone. You can find out so much from them that you’ll want to have a go.

“Just give it a try. Just give it a try.”

items.title: Why You Should Consider a Foster Care Career In 2026
items.snippet: If you're searching for a more meaningful path in 2026, fostering could be the perfect next step. In this blog, we explore why now is a great time to become a foster carer—covering the rewards, opportunities, and real impact you can make by starting a career that changes lives every day. The post Why You Should Consider a Foster Care Career In 2026 appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
It’s a new year, which means many of us are thinking about our goals and dreams for 2026. Perhaps you want to improve your health, pick up a new hobby, or plan a once-in-a-lifetime trip. But have you thought about starting a new career where you’ll truly make a difference every single day?

From learning new skills and meeting like-minded people to having meaningful experiences and doing something that aligns with your values, join us as we explore why 2026 is the perfect time to switch careers to fostering.

Why is foster care important?

Careers in the foster care system are in high demand due to a national shortage of foster families. Every year, around 36,000 children come into care; however, there are not enough foster parents available to care for them. This means vulnerable children are more likely to be:

  • Separated from their siblings.
  • Experience frequent moves.
  • Live in residential care.
  • Have their education disrupted.
  • Live far away from the communities they’re familiar with.

Growing up without the stability of a safe and loving home can affect every aspect of a child’s development, from their ability to form relationships to the way they process and regulate emotions.

That’s why foster care is one of the most rewarding careers you can choose. Whether you provide a child with a safe home for a few nights or support them through school and prepare them for independent living, the work you’ll do as a foster parent can make all the difference to their life-long outcomes.

Here are six more reasons why you should consider a foster care career in 2026.

6 reasons to start fostering in 2026

 

It’s a career that truly makes a difference

Unlike many desk jobs, fostering actively makes a world of difference. It’s crucial in helping to ensure the next generation of children grow up in healthy, secure environments with the chance to reach their full potential.

Foster carers don’t just provide a safe place for children to live – they are role models, teachers and parents all rolled into one. With the help of foster families, foster children can learn to overcome trust issues, build confidence and grow into successful young adults with promising careers of their own. Many even go on to have careers in the foster care system themselves, creating a positive cycle of change.

It’s not only life-changing for the foster children, but it’s also a rich, rewarding experience for you and your family. Fostering can open your eyes to new cultures, teach you things about yourself you never knew and give you a deeper purpose in life.

You’ll leave a legacy that matters

Fostering is a career that enables you to leave a legacy that matters. Whether you offer long-term or short-term fostering, you’ll help children by passing on wisdom, supporting them through life’s ups and downs, and creating family traditions.

It can be little things, like teaching a child how to brush their teeth, to bigger things like helping a teenager get back onto a positive path. Everything you do as a foster parent goes towards helping children develop independence and become the best versions of themselves. Now that’s something to be proud of.

Thousands of children need a home

When a child enters the care system, they are scared and confused. Being separated from their birth family, even those who have been abusive or neglectful, can cause a child significant stress.

In England, there are over 80 thousand children considered looked after, and they need loving, supportive foster parents who can provide them with the stability they need to thrive.

When you decide to embark upon a foster care career, you’re not just choosing a job to pay the bills. It’s a commitment to giving every child the opportunity to live a happy, healthy life.

You don’t need any experience

You don’t need to have superpowers to be a brilliant foster parent. Skills you’ve learned in previous jobs, through having your own children or nuggets of wisdom you’ve picked up in life, can play a big part in your role as a foster carer.

Transferable skills like empathy, being a good listener, compassion, resilience, an open mind and having a bucket-load of patience are all traits we look for in future foster parents.

You don’t even need previous experience in caring for a child. Of course, this is an added bonus if you have, but it’s the personal qualities that stand out to us. As long as you’re determined to make a difference, we can help you become a great foster parent.

Professional development and 24/7 support

With many careers, it’s easy to hit a ceiling; however, being a foster parent means you’re always learning something new. At FCA, we understand that fostering is a career, which is why we actively encourage your professional development.

When you join us, you’ll have access to our high-quality training courses where you can enhance your existing skills or specialise in specific areas, such as fostering children with trauma, disabilities, or autism. Our ongoing approach to training will equip you with the knowledge and skills needed to care for children with varying needs.

Fostering with FCA is also like joining a big family. You’ll have a network of professionals at your fingertips, as well as a community of other like-minded foster parents to share experiences with. From dedicated social work support and therapy services to peer support groups and regular fun events in the community, you’ll realise that when you foster a child with FCA, you’re never alone on your fostering journey.

You’ll receive a generous fostering allowance

Fostering a child has its challenges, so it’s only right that we reward you for your hard work and dedication.

Independent fostering agencies (IFAs) pay more than local authorities, but the exact amount you get depends on where you live and the child you’re fostering.

The allowances cover all the costs of caring for a child, including meals, clothes, bills and presents. You also get a minimum of 14 nights paid respite, which is where the child in your care lives with another foster family while you have a well-earned break.

There are also additional bonuses for the length of service and hitting fostering milestones. The fostering allowance also gives you a number of tax exemptions and won’t affect any of your existing benefits.

Start your fostering career today

We could give you 101 reasons why you should consider a career in foster care and why it is so important, but the main one will always be the fact that you get the chance to transform a child’s life.

If you want more information about fostering, download our Beginner’s Guide to Fostering a Child handbook. It’s everything you need to know about fostering in one handy place. Alternatively, you can get in touch, and we’ll answer any questions you have.

items.title: Annette and Gerry’s Journey into Fostering
items.snippet: Annette and her husband Gerry have been fostering with FCA Northern Ireland since 2020. Here is their fostering story. The post Annette and Gerry’s Journey into Fostering appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
Annette and Gerry’s fostering story

Annette and her husband, Gerry, have been fostering since 2020. Together, they have three children of their own two daughters and a son and our proud grandparents to four grandsons.  Before becoming a foster parent, Annette spent 16 years working in a residential home supporting adults with learning disabilities, where she was a deputy manager. Today, her life centres around caring for her foster children and her grandchildren which she finds incredibly rewarding.

Why foster?

Annette tells us what made her consider fostering “I think I always wanted to be a mum. I come from a big family of ten children, and I’m the fourth eldest, so having a busy household felt natural to me. After having my own children, I still found myself talking about fostering. I always thought that if I had the space and a spare bedroom, I’d love to do it. I admired people who fostered, I just thought it was brilliant.”

“I never had the fear of ‘how would I give them back?’ If you do a good job, you know that’s part of the role, and you’ve helped a child. When our eldest eventually moved out, we had a spare room. One evening, while my youngest daughter and I were having dinner, she said, “Mammy, all my life I’ve heard you and Daddy talk about fostering. Now we’ve got a spare room what’s stopping you?”

That very night whilst scrolling through Facebook we saw an advert for FCA and clicked on it, that’s how it all started.”

 

For their family, fostering wasn’t a huge shock. “I was a bit nervous at the start, because you never know what challenges you’re going to face,” Annette explains. But their children and wider family were supportive. In fact, fostering runs in the family as Gerry’s brother and his wife are also foster parents, so it wasn’t a big surprise that Annette and Gerry were taking the step themselves.

One particularly heart-warming story involves a pair of twin boys. FCA called to match one of the twins with Annette and Gerry, while the other had already been matched with Annette’s cousin, who also fosters with FCA. At the time, Annette didn’t realise it was her cousin, though she recognised the family name. Although the cousins had never met and didn’t know they were both fostering with FCA, everything became clear once the connection was made. The boys were then able to meet regularly and form a strong bond. “It’s really brilliant,” Annette says. “My cousin is like a sister now.”

Best fostering moments

“When I think about some of my best fostering moments, our first foster child will always have a special place in my heart. Being our first, he made a huge impression on us.”  Annette explains.

“It’s the same with our little girl we have living with us now, watching her grow in confidence, seeing her feel safe enough to be herself, is incredible and that makes everything worthwhile.”

For me, the best moments are seeing the children blossom, seeing their confidence grow, and knowing they feel safe enough to just be themselves. When a child can truly be themselves, without having to put on a front, you know they’re content and happy. That’s what fostering is all about.

Support from FCA

Annette describes the support she has received from FCA as “amazing and outstanding.” She speaks very highly of her supervising social worker, who she feels she can confide in without judgment, gives her the space to express her feelings openly and she is always available if needed.

“She’s one of the best social workers, she should be cloned,” Annette says.

Suming up her fostering experience

When Annette reflects on her fostering journey, she describes it as interesting and challenging but above all, it’s the best thing she has ever done.

“I would have loved to do it years ago,” she says, “but at the time we just didn’t have the space. We didn’t have a spare bedroom.” Even so, she has no doubts that fostering came into her life at exactly the right moment.

For Annette, fostering has been incredibly rewarding, she has formed strong friendships and become part of a close-knit community of fellow foster parents. One of her favourite parts of fostering is the monthly support group, which she looks forward. She values the opportunity to share experiences, learn from others, and gain fresh perspectives. Hearing how other foster parents approach similar challenges has helped her think differently and broaden her understanding. “It really opens your mind,” she explains.  Ultimately, while the impact on the children is what matters most, Annette says the friendships, family connects and support she’s found through fostering and through FCA have been truly amazing.

What would your advice be to new foster parents?

“One of the biggest lessons I’ve learned from fostering is not to take things personally. Children who come into your home might say some of the worst things imaginable. Often, they simply don’t know how to express how they’re feeling. It’s important to separate yourself from it, even though it can feel very personal in the moment.  I genuinely enjoy fostering. One thing I’d say to anyone considering it is: absolutely go to the support groups. Honestly, it makes everything so much easier. You learn so much and knowing you’re not alone makes a huge difference.”

items.title: From Teaching to Fostering, a Worthwhile Transition
items.snippet: Alison, a foster parent with FCA South East, shares her journey from teaching to fostering. The post From Teaching to Fostering, a Worthwhile Transition appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
Alison’s fostering story

Foster parent Alison from FCA South East shares her journey from teaching to fostering. Here is her story

After 37 years in the classroom, I was always determined that I would retire as close to my 60th birthday as possible.  I wanted to spend my retirement finding out more about life and enjoying new experiences, be it volunteering, learning new skills or travelling.

I was aware that I would miss the company of young people and the joy of being with them as they grew and discovered the world around them.  I felt I still had skills to offer.  An invitation from the FCA fostering agency to attend an introductory meeting to looked interesting and a warm welcome from the social worker encouraged me to go further.

I opted for short term fostering; I welcome children and young people for just a few days or weeks.  In some cases it may only be for 24 hours: I currently welcome a young person every month for an overnight stay.  The reasons why the young people need to come to me vary: it may be because their full-time foster parent is ill, or there is family illness, a bereavement or a holiday was booked before the child came to live with them.

Since retiring eight years ago I have welcomed around 20 young people aged between 5 and 17.  and have greatly enjoyed being with the children who have stayed with me.  One young man came to me every summer for two weeks from age 11 to 17.  He first appeared as a very shy, nervous boy but grew into a confident adult who was ready to take on the world.  The longest period that a young person stayed with me was an asylum seeker who was with me for 11 months.  I’m an approved parent and child carer and have welcomed two new mothers with their babies for short breaks. There have naturally been one or two challenges, I have learnt how to manage type 1 diabetes and epilepsy, but our training gives us a good basis and the social work team is very supportive.  There are regular support meetings for foster parents and it is always a pleasure to get together.

The approval process begins with a short introductory course which is designed to give the prospective foster parent an understanding of what is involved followed by training with and assessment by a social worker.  I found the training to be thorough; it often covered aspects of child development that I wished I had known more about during my career in education.

I have appreciated the flexibility of being able to say when I could welcome a child and when it was not possible.  This has entirely fit in with my retirement plans and so doesn’t interfere with being able to accept opportunities to enjoy the theatre and cultural life and to take trips abroad.  Information about a child is usually provided in advance and I only agree to welcome children if I am confident that I can offer them a good experience; as it’s just me at home that can be very important.  In addition, the fostering allowance has provided a very welcome top up to my pension.  As a Waspi woman this has been particularly beneficial.

Becoming a foster parent has been one of the best decisions I have ever made and I can wholeheartedly recommend it.  Spending time with some wonderful young people, having fun with them, listening to them, cooking and gardening with them and laughing with them has helped to make my retirement truly special.

items.title: What Are Empty Nesters and Why They Make Great Foster Carers
items.snippet: While having children is not a requirement for becoming a foster carer, the experience provides skills that are highly beneficial in caring for a young person. The post What Are Empty Nesters and Why They Make Great Foster Carers appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
As parents, we endeavour to raise children who are healthy, happy, and ready to take on the world. Watching them grow into confident young adults and eventually leave the family home is such a natural part of life, but when that day comes, it can stir up a whirlwind of emotions. After years of sharing laughter, teaching life skills, and helping them believe in themselves, the house suddenly feels a little quieter. It is a big change, and adjusting to this new chapter takes time.

What Is an Empty Nester?

An empty nester is a parent whose children have moved out of the family home. Young adults leave for many reasons, such as attending university, starting a career, moving in with a partner, or simply beginning a new chapter in their lives.

This transition brings a new lease of life for some parents, offering the freedom to try new things and explore new hobbies with their newly found time. However, for others, the change can be emotionally challenging.

What Challenges Do Empty Nesters Face?

It is natural for empty nesters to experience feelings of loneliness or uncertainty as the house becomes quieter. The familiar routines that once shaped the day, washing uniforms, cooking meals, supervising homework, being a taxi driver or simply knowing that a child was home safe, are no longer there.

Many parents find this shift surprisingly emotional. Often called ‘empty nester syndrome’, it can bring sadness, loneliness, and even a sense of grief. Missing the structure, the laughter, and the sense of purpose that once filled the day is common, and adjusting to a quieter home takes time.

How Can Fostering Support Empty Nesters?

Even when children grow up and move out, the instinct to support, care for, and guide others often remains strong. Fostering offers a meaningful way to open both your heart and your home to a child or young person who needs stability, understanding and encouragement.

Fostering is not about replacing grown children. Instead, it brings new purpose and an opportunity to make a meaningful difference in a young life. It allows parents to continue offering warmth, reassurance, and a sense of belonging to children and young people who need it most.

Why Empty Nesters Make Great Foster Carers

Empty nesters often make excellent foster carers for many reasons. Years of raising children provide valuable experience in navigating the challenges and milestones of childhood and adolescence. While having children is not a requirement for becoming a foster carer, this experience provides skills that are highly beneficial in caring for a young person.

Empty nesters understand the daily responsibilities of parenting and preparing a child for independence in a safe and caring environment, which is the overall goal of fostering. Over the years, they also develop patience, effective communication, problem-solving skills, and emotional understanding, all of which are essential qualities for successful foster carers.

Thinking About Becoming a Foster Carer?

The home may feel quieter now, but this next chapter can be filled with connection, purpose, and the joy of making a lasting difference in a child or young person’s life.

If you are thinking about becoming a foster carer or have any questions about how fostering can help fill your empty nest, contact our recruitment team, who can answer any questions you have and provide you with information on the excellent support, training and allowance Swiis offers.

items.title: Reflecting on a Year of Fostering Successes
items.snippet: As 2025 comes to a close, we’re celebrating the milestones that made this year so special at FCA—from Ofsted praise to national TV moments. In this blog, we reflect on the achievements made possible by our incredible foster parents and look ahead to another year of changing children’s lives for the better. items.content:
As 2025 draws to a close and the busy Christmas period begins, we’re taking a moment to reflect on the past year at FCA.

From the Big Sing Off and recognition from Ofsted to having one of our foster parents featured on Katie Piper’s Weekend Escapes, 2025 has been an incredible journey.

But we couldn’t do it without you, our dedicated foster parents. Every day you show up for vulnerable children and provide therapeutic foster care, which helps them build a brighter future.

So join us as we celebrate our proudest achievements as a community this year and look forward to the new year.

FCA reflections on a new year

When you foster with FCA, you don’t do it alone; you’re part of a community committed to helping you, your family, and the children you foster thrive.

Whether you’ve been fostering with us for a while and want to relive some of the best moments of 2025, or are new to FCA and want to see what it’s really like to foster with us, let’s explore the highlights of the past 12 months.

Rated ‘Outstanding’ by Ofsted

Three of our fantastic teams were rated ‘Outstanding’ by Ofsted this year:

  • Thames Valley: Received their second consecutive ‘Outstanding’ rating from Ofsted, who said, ‘Children in the care of FCA Thames Valley make exceptional progress while living with their foster families.’
  • North East: In 2022, FCA North East received a ‘Good’ Ofsted rating, but earlier this year, they were commended for ‘helping children to settle, build trusted relationships with their foster families and feel loved and cared for’ and became recognised as ‘Outstanding.’
  • Yorks and Lincs: Stepped up from ‘Good’ to ‘Outstanding’ in May this year, with Ofsted praising the team for being ‘relentless in wanting to do the right thing for the children.’

The Ofsted reports included comments from children, such as ‘Life is amazing right now because I feel loved,’ and from foster parents who said things like, ‘They are genuine people and listen when you have any problems.’

These results and remarks demonstrate our commitment supporting foster parents and changing the lives of vulnerable children and young people.

Participation dream teams

Every region at FCA has a participation team that helps children and young people build their confidence and connect with others by delivering activities and events for our foster families throughout the year.

From celebrations and fun days to picnics and days out, our participation dream teams work tirelessly to help foster children make new positive memories. Here are just some of the highlights from this year:

  • Annual Achievements Day: In January, FCA Yorks and Lincs celebrated the achievements of children and young people with a day of music, dancing, and joy.
  • Life Skills Weekend: During the Easter holidays, FCA Midlands hosted a residential life skills weekend in Cannock Chase, where children learned how to cook, budget and work as a team, while also taking part in fun activities.
  • Charity Fun Day: In June, every region of FCA and FCA Scotland came together to raise money for charity by getting active and and taking on the Going the Extra Mile challenge. This involved walking, running, dancing or cycling as many miles as possible over a weekend. We managed to cover over 2,850 miles and raised an incredible £3,854.
  • Festival of Achievement: FCA Midlands hosted a Festival of Achievement to celebrate the accomplishments of children and young people. From rolling out a red carpet and fancy dress theme to unicorn pony rides, circus skills workshops, and pedal carts, the day was truly unforgettable.
  • Fun Fest: This summer, FCA South Western’s fun fest gave foster families across the region a chance to relax, have fun, and connect with others. From a bouncy castle and live music to crafts, face painting and the chance to sit inside a real fire engine, the team pulled out all the stops and made the day truly special.

The Big Sing Off

The Big Sing Off is our annual show-stopping event, which brings children, young people, foster parents, and our incredible teams together for a day of fun, laughter, and singing.

This year’s theme was ‘Heroes and Villains,’ inspiring some creative costumes and song choices, such as FCA Yorks and Lincs’ rendition of Revolting Children from the musical Matilda, which won them first place.

From bouncy castles, magic mirrors and candy floss to DJ workshops, face painting, and a silent disco, the event was packed with activities for the whole family to enjoy.

One of our foster parents said, “What a brilliant day! It was so lovely to be able to get involved and see the smiles on the children’s faces. I had a cry at a couple of the choirs – amazing! Can’t wait for next year.”

From fostering stories to national TV

Throughout the year, many of our foster parents have shared their fostering stories with us, from what inspired them to begin their journey to the ups and downs of foster parent life; every single one is truly inspiring.

items.title: Meet Gareth Thomas: Education Advisor
items.snippet: Gareth has worked for Swiis for 8 years and loves working with the children in foster care who need educational support. The post Meet Gareth Thomas: Education Advisor appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
The focus of our foster carers and the team around the foster carer is to care for and improve the lives of children and young people who are unable to stay with their birth parents. A huge part of a child’s everyday life is their education, which is critical for a child’s development. That is why at Swiis, we have dedicated Education Advisors to help provide extensive support to children and young people, ensuring that they have the best opportunities possible to achieve academic success.

Meet Gareth Thomas, the person behind this important role! Gareth has worked for Swiis for 8 years and loves working with the children in foster care who need educational support.

In his free time, Gareth loves travelling and embarking on long treks, which not only clears his mind but also allows him to discover new places and meet interesting people. He has a passion for cooking, rugby, exercise, and DIY projects – he even recently converted an old van into a campervan! A fun fact about Gareth is that he once taught young people how to drive on a race track at Castle Combe. His dream destinations are Vietnam and Thailand, where he looks forward to immersing himself in the vibrant culture and cuisine.

Let us explore Gareth’s role as an Education Advisor, where he shares his insights on guiding foster children to unlock their full potential.

Your Role at Swiis Foster Care

What is your job title, and how long have you worked for Swiis?

“I am the Education Advisor for Midlands and South, and I have been employed with Swiis for nearly 8 years.”

“My role also allows me to support our placement support team in organising participation events and attending foster carer support groups to advise on how young people can be supported in their education.”

What motivated you to work in foster care?

“I wanted to learn how to support children and young people outside of their school environment, support foster families and help improve their lives inside and outside of school.”

What does your role as an Education Advisor entail?

“It is always evolving, however, my main responsibilities are to empower foster carers to support children’s education and outcomes and to ensure all children looked after within our care have the best opportunities to enable them to achieve good outcomes in their education, health and well-being.”

What does a day in your role look like?

“A normal day would include discussing issues and concerns that have been raised with other professionals in a multi-agency context, ensuring information to support young people is shared, and to monitor, record and update young people’s progress and to attend education meetings. I am also involved in the participation of events and activities throughout the year.”

Where does your department fit in the fostering process?

“Once foster carers are approved, I contact them and offer advice and guidance on how children and young people can be supported in their education. This would include offering guidance concerning policy, children’s rights, school transitions and those young people transitioning to independence, such as university, work and other apprenticeships. Throughout the time the children are with our foster carers, I support and advocate for the children and foster carers.”

Fostering Insights

How do you help provide foster carers with the correct educational support at home?

“Every child has a right to education, but some children who experience care, struggle in education for many reasons, including having to move to new areas on multiple occasions. This often means having to spend the first few days or weeks in the new foster home without education. My role would be to provide the foster carer with the appropriate resources to support the children’s learning, depending on their needs and abilities. Secondary to this, I would work with other agencies and schools to ensure that the most suitable school provision can be sourced, and the young person is given the opportunity to attend school at the earliest opportunity. As well as this being vital for their learning, it is also important for them to make friendships with their peers, appropriate adult relationships with adults and to give them social opportunities within their local community.”

How does your role help to support the child in care and their foster carer?

“I would normally introduce myself and explain my role to new foster carers so they are aware of how they can be supported with any educational issues or concerns. Types of support include training in how to advocate for their young people during PEP (Personal Education Plan) and EHCp (Education, Health Care Plan) meetings, advising of their rights and responsibilities, advising foster carers and young people in how to use and access resources that will enhance and support their learning.”

What are some of the most memorable achievements you have seen from a child or young person?

“Hearing the feedback from a young unaccompanied person who attended a university experience visit with the Swiis Midlands and South team. They informed me that the day would ‘stay with them forever’ and that it had inspired them to do well in their studies and attend a university in the future. The young person in question has since moved on to further education and is doing very well in his studies.

“Another memorable experience was being with a group of foster children on a day visit to the Donkey Sanctuary and seeing them all play, laugh and eat ice cream together. They loved the day out. This type of event offers children the chance to interact with peers and adults in healthy, supportive environments, helping them learn social and life skills necessary for future independence.

“Also, producing a Podcast with a young person who shared their thoughts and feelings on meaningful topics that affected their lives, such as bullying and identity. The young person felt extremely proud and hoped that it would help other young people. It is essential to provide foster children with a voice for their well-being and development, enabling them to express their emotions and thoughts. It also helps to shape decisions that impact their lives.”

What do you think are the best qualities a foster carer should have?

“The best qualities I think a foster carer should have in supporting young people are to show they are interested and invested in helping them with their well-being and safety by listening to them, showing them warmth, being inclusive of their needs and including them as part of the family. By appropriately advocating for their needs when communicating with health, education and social services will also show the young person they are being supported and listened to. The best qualities foster carers can possess are a combination of emotional, practical, and interpersonal abilities.”

Gareth’s perspective on the educational support offered by Swiis highlights our commitment to empowering foster children and young people to achieve academic success. By showcasing the teams and individuals who make Swiis exceptional, we aim to demonstrate our dedication to supporting foster children, young people and their foster carers every step of the way.

items.title: Foster Care Cost of Living: Managing Finances While Fostering
items.snippet: The cost of living is rising—but that doesn’t have to stop you from fostering. In this blog, we explore how FCA supports carers financially and share practical budgeting tips to help you feel confident about your money, so you can focus on giving children in care the support and stability they deserve. The post Foster Care Cost of Living: Managing Finances While Fostering appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
If you’re thinking about fostering, it’s only natural to wonder how it will affect your finances.

Money is a hot topic for most families up and down the UK, especially with various doom and gloom news reports highlighting the rise in the cost of living and shrinkflation.

The good news is that when you foster with FCA, you receive a generous fostering allowance that’s typically tax-free. But it’s still wise to take steps to make your money go even further.

That’s why in this article, we’re exploring money management as a foster parent, from why budgeting matters to tips for making everyday savings, so you feel in control and ready to make a difference in the lives of children you foster.

Why budgeting matters when fostering

Most of us know that good money management helps you stay on top of what income you’ve got coming in and what bills and essential spending you’ve got going out. Here are some other benefits of keeping a keen eye on your finances:

  • Prevents overspending and credit card debt.
  • Allows you to put money aside for emergencies.
  • Gives you scope to save for long-term goals, such as home improvements or that once-in-a-lifetime holiday.
  • Helps you save for fun activities, special occasions, and weekends away.
  • Keeps you in control and fully aware of your financial situation, which can reduce stress and anxiety.

Helps you provide a stable home for children in your care where all their needs are met and they have opportunities to explore their interests.

Regardless of which type of fostering you choose, during your assessment, we’ll take a look at your financial situation to make sure you don’t have any financial obligations that could make it difficult for you to meet the needs of the children you foster. We also do this to ensure that if you experience a gap between caring for children, it won’t put you in a tricky position.

This means it’s a good idea to get on top of your finances before applying to avoid delays during the assessment process. Below are our tips to help you get started.

Tips for managing your money as a foster parent

Create a realistic budget 

The key to creating a budget that you’ll stick to is making it realistic. If your budget is overly strict, the chances are you’ll find it difficult to maintain, so be honest with yourself when you start the process.

Obviously, your budget will include money you receive from your fostering allowance, benefits and job (if you work while fostering), as well as non-negotiable bills that you pay every month, such as gas and electric, water, mortgage or rent, and insurance.

However, to create a realistic budget that helps you stay conscious of where your money is going, you need to review your past and present expenditures. So download your bank statements and work out how much you currently spend on groceries, subscriptions, hobbies, and treats and add these to your budget. This way, you’ll see how much you have left over for savings or something you really want to buy.

Set yourself achievable targets 

If you want to reduce spending or save for something special, instead of eliminating everything that brings you joy from your budget, set yourself some realistic targets that you can actually achieve.

For example, if your grocery bill has gotten a bit out of hand and you find yourself throwing food away, you could aim to cut it by £20 or £30. If you realise you have multiple streaming subscriptions but only really use one, you could cancel the others.

These little tweaks to your spending will add up over time, helping you reach saving goals faster while still being able to spend money on the things you enjoy.

Use a budgeting tool that works for you 

Throughout the year unexpected expenses are more than likely to occur, so there’s no point creating a budget and never looking at it again.

Find a budgeting tool that doesn’t feel like a chore to use so you’ll engage with it regularly. Here are some examples:

  • Planners: If you prefer to put pen to paper, a budgeting planner could work for you.
  • Spreadsheets: If you are a dab hand at Excel, why not create a spreadsheet? Or download the Money Saving Expert’s ready-to-use budget planner.
  • Banks: Many banks offer budgeting tools in their apps, where you can set up categories and track your spending automatically.
  • Apps: There are now hundreds of budgeting apps available, such as Emma, that allow you to track all your bank accounts, credit rating and mortgage deal in one place.

Life as a foster parent can get busy, so set yourself a monthly reminder to review your spending and adjust your budget if needed. Before you know it, budgeting will become a breeze.

Focus on your own financial goals 

In this day and age, we’re bombarded with advertisements from retailers, travel agents and influencers persuading us to part with our money for a product, experience, or service.

Couple this with our social media feeds being flooded with photos of piles of Christmas presents, new cars, and holidays, and it can be easy to get sucked into buying something you don’t need or can’t really afford to ‘keep up’ with friends and family.

In reality, everyone’s financial situation is different, and you never truly know how other families fund their lifestyles or if their finances are in good health. Take buying a new car, for example, over 80% are purchased using finance. And figures also show that 84% of adults in the UK had taken out credit or a loan between May 2023 and 2024.

If you’re feeling pressured to match the lifestyles of others, try to remind yourself of your own financial goals so you don’t end up living beyond your means.

Be a savvy shopper 

Even in a cost-of-living crisis, there are some things you just can’t cut back on. But you can still save money by being a savvy shopper.

When you foster with FCA, as part of our support for foster parents, you receive access to The Exchange, our exclusive foster parent rewards platform. All you have to do is log in, and you’ll find discount codes, instant vouchers, and reloadable cards that help you save money on everything from daily essentials to holidays, days out, and more.

It even includes a handy calculator to help you work out how much you could save, along with a SmartSpending app that gives you access to discounts and deals on the go.

Here are a few more easy ways to save money when you shop: 

  • Use loyalty cards: From free drinks and exclusive discounts to vouchers for days out, holidays and more, loyalty cards are a really simple way to save cash.
  • Buy pre-loved items: Whether you need a lawn mower, a bicycle for your foster child, or something else, Vinted, eBay, and Facebook Marketplace are your friends for saving money, with many items sold ‘like new’.
  • Meal plan: Save money and prevent waste by only buying the food you need for your weekly mean plan.
  • Have groceries delivered: When groceries are delivered, not only does it save time, but it also prevents you from adding things you don’t really need to your trolley, and you can see the running total while you shop.
  • Buy discounted food through apps: At the end of each day, shops, restaurants, and cafes often have food that they won’t be able to sell the next day, but is too good to be thrown away. These businesses use apps like Too Good to Go to sell mystery bags of food and drink at a fraction of the original price.

Managing your money may sound like a bit of a slog, but over time, it’ll become second nature and you’ll feel better knowing that you have your finances under control. It’ll also free up your mind to concentrate on helping children and young people heal from their past, create new positive memories, and work towards a brighter future.

Get in touch today

If you’d like to learn more about fostering, including finances, training, and support for children in foster care, call us on 0800 098 4148 or submit an enquiry form, and we’ll call you!

items.title: Swiis Superstars Release Their First Music Track
items.snippet: In our Yorkshire region, a group of musically talented individuals known as the Swiis Superstars have come together to create their very first original music track called ‘Our Moments’! The post Swiis Superstars Release Their First Music Track appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
The young people at Swiis Foster Care are filled with creativity and talent. In our Yorkshire region, a group of musically talented individuals known as the Swiis Superstars have come together to create their very first original music track called ‘Our Moments’!

In the lead-up to their production day, the young people dedicated time to planning, collaborating, and bringing their ideas to life. The group decided that their song would focus on growing up in foster care, and each young person played an important part in the creative process.

One young person, J, a talented lyricist and rapper, wrote the lyrics by drawing inspiration from his own experience in foster care. Alison, a Swiis Senior Placement Support Worker, said, “The speed at which J was able to put the words together was incredible!”

Once the lyrics were complete, R began experimenting with different sounds on a guitar to complement J’s words. After the group agreed on the perfect sound, E added in additional guitar tones, while P and S helped to create the beats, and PB added rhythm through their impressive beatboxing skills.

One of the Swiis young people, G, also played a big part in creating the song and was eager to use their talent on the vocals. Unfortunately, they were not able to attend on production day, but we are really looking forward to hearing their musical talent in the future!

When production day arrived, the Swiis local office was transformed into a lively recording studio, giving everyone the perfect space to come together and create their brand-new track.

Once the song was complete, the group also wanted to create a cover for their track. They chose a dragon to symbolise courage, and one of our talented young people brought that vision to life by mocking up a design.

We are incredibly proud of the Swiis Superstars for their teamwork and creativity throughout this project. They have such great passion and talent for music and have created a track to be proud of, and we are thrilled to share it with you!

items.title: Children of Foster Carers – Holly’s Story
items.snippet: Holly’s parents began fostering with Swiis in 2010, and shortly after their approval, they welcomed a foster sibling group of two females and two males into their home. The post Children of Foster Carers – Holly’s Story appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
Children of foster carers play an essential role in the fostering household, and they contribute so much to the lives of the foster children and young people placed in their home. The patience, understanding and support that children of foster carers give to foster children and young people does not go unnoticed, and we are thankful for their dedication to helping transform the lives of others less fortunate.

We had the opportunity to speak with Holly about her experience, who, along with her older brother, grew up as a child of foster carers. Holly’s parents began fostering with Swiis in 2010, and shortly after their approval, they welcomed a foster sibling group of two females and two males into their home. With the foster children ranging in age from infancy to six years old, Holly, who was just nine at the time, quickly went from being the youngest in her family to having four younger foster children in the home.

She recalls her dad introduced the idea of becoming a foster carer, and because her grandmother had been fostering for years, Holly already understood what it meant to welcome children in need into her home.

“I remember being really excited about it and excited for my dad’s new career path.”

Holly shared with us some of her favourite earliest memories with the foster children.

 “The female foster children and I all used to love it when I would do their makeup and paint their nails when we were younger. I take pride in knowing that they have always looked up to me and I’ve loved watching them grow up into beautiful, strong, and kind young women.”

Over the years, Holly has been amazed at watching each of the foster children in the home grow and thrive. She has seen the youngest foster boys adapt to the challenges of high school and overcome any social difficulties.

“I’ve loved seeing the youngest boys grow up and mature, and love that the youngest often wants to spend time with me just to chat about his day and ask me about my life. The two female foster children are at that age now where we can talk like friends as well as sisters, and I love being able to talk and gossip about girl stuff and have fun with them outside of ‘older sibling duties’!”

As Holly became no longer the youngest in her family, it meant that there was a shift in the role she played in the household, she stepped up, taking on more responsibilities.

“I feel like I took on a lot of responsibilities from a younger age as I felt a bond early on and wanted to help care for them the best I could. The last few years I’ve occasionally helped my parents with babysitting when they want to go out for dinner or enjoy a holiday away, or even small moments when they want to go out for a walk. I’ve always tried to help where I can in looking after them.”

Individuals like Holly leave a lasting impact on the lives of foster children and young people. She has played a significant role in creating a safe, stable, and loving environment by being a trusted and caring role model for them. Her dedication is a reminder of how the entire family plays a crucial part in the fostering experience, making a meaningful difference in the lives of those they welcome into their home.

items.title: Children of Foster Carers’ Week
items.snippet: Children of Foster Carers' Week is taking place from 13th to 19th October 2025. The post Children of Foster Carers’ Week appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
Children of Foster Carers’ Week is an annual campaign organised by The Fostering Network, taking place from 13th to 19th October 2025. The week was created to recognise and celebrate the incredible role that the children of foster carers play within a fostering household.

Whether a foster carer’s child is young, a teenager, or has grown up and moved out of the family home, the children of foster carers often provide support to both their parents and the foster child or young person. Some responsibilities they have can include:

  • Being a positive role model for the child or young person
  • Supporting with everyday tasks, such as school pick-ups or cooking
  • Sharing personal things like toys, books, or games
  • Helping them learn about responsibilities within the home
  • Offering a listening ear and someone they can talk to

Throughout the week, we will be sharing case studies from children of foster carers to highlight their experiences and the vital role they play in the fostering household. These stories highlight how fostering has impacted their life and the amazing memories they have had watching foster children and young people develop over their time together.

To kick start Children of Foster Carers week, we spoke to Lockie and Pippa, who shared what their favourite memory with a foster child or young person has been so far, what they enjoy most about being part of a fostering household, how their responsibilities may have changed over time, and any additional thoughts they wanted to share.

Lockie – Aged 9

What has been your most memorable or special experience with a foster child?

“When we all went to Disneyland at Christmas. It was good having L to go on all the rides with, especially the bigger ones, because my sisters don’t like them. We like the Spider-Man ride the most, shooting webs with our hands and wearing the 3D glasses.”

What do you enjoy most about having a foster child in your home?

“L plays football with me in the garden and plays Roblox with me on the Xbox. He’s getting better at playing with me, and it’s good having a boy to play outside with at football.”

Have your responsibilities at home changed since your family began fostering? If so, how?

“I help him and remind him how to be good, especially because my little sister copies, and we need to teach her to be kind.”

Pippa – Aged 15

What has been your most memorable or special experience with a foster child?

“I have had lots of lovely memories of past and present little ones, building special bonds that last a lifetime, Christmases full of excitement and magic.

“Times when I come home from school to be greeted with 2 little ones chanting my name as I walk through the door, both wanting big hugs.”

What do you enjoy most about having a foster child in your home?

“Fun and laughter everywhere, to stay with me forever.”

Have your responsibilities at home changed since your family began fostering? If so, how?

“They have stayed the same even though things have changed. I enjoy playing with toys and reading stories.”

Is there anything else you would like to share about your experiences?

“I have found it to be really positive having my parents be able to foster, even though it does have its sad times, like when they move on to adoption.”
